author: turbinezach
content: if it's not too much trouble, could y'all delete https://gitter.im/ethereum/ethereumj because of spammers and confused users, or at least mark https://github.com/ethereum/ethereumj as deprecated within Ethereum settings? Thanks.

author: Deleted User
content: Afaik EGL and MEV/Flashbots is mostly possible because geth is open source. (They use modified versions of it). Has there been consideration into making it closed source to protect against these endeavors?

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm pretty sure pretty much everyone working in this space would be pretty strongly against that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Almost all of us got into this because we prefer more open and collaborative systems in general.  I'm sure there are some exceptions to this, but I'm reasonably confident that they are in the minority among core devs and contributors.

author: Deleted User
content: There is much to be said on this. But in short If things like EGL and MEV gets out of control then it might be too late to go closed source so its something that has to be considered sooner than later imo.

author: Deleted User
content: It sounds as if im fudding but i am being serious ðŸ™‚ it would be prudent to find out wether the pros and cons of being open source so far are worth it

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think closed source is ever the right option when you are trying to build a public good.

author: sky.cactus
content: As a user, I would immediately stop using Ethereum if it all went closed source.  I'm in this for open finance, not a remaking of the legacy financial system.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm here to try to make the world a better place, not just to make money.  IMO, that means accepting that censorship resistance means people will sometimes do/say things you don't agree with but being willing to live in a world where they are allowed to do such things.

author: sky.cactus
content: In this case, some people are doing a thing that I may not agree with, but I accept that it is within their right to act in a way they think is best.

author: Deleted User
content: After thinking more about it going closed source will probably create bigger problems than it solves. I kinda regret bringing it up now but i will leave it up for posterity

author: Deleted User
content: Thank you for the discussion

author: 0xsadcat
content:
<@!329594653097721856> ""scaling with Rollups" == "Ethereum is shit, we give up on it, let someone else scale us""
I think that's incorrect, in particular about zkrollups. Zkrollups offer the best possible scalability because they only have to transfer state difference along with a correctness proof, so they will always win over all other scaling strategies. At the same time, proof generation is extremely expensive (I think some are starting to even use fgpas now) so in its current form it's fundamentally incompatible with decentralized l1. A rollup is currently the only way to retain decentralization with zkrollups.

author: 0xsadcat
content: Optimistic rollups are more questionable. It's very possible that with more sensible gas limits they wouldn't be needed at all, because l1 would be enough until zkrollups mature.

author: butta
content: https://etherscan.io/blocks

author: butta
content: >30M gas limit

author: 0xsadcat
content: I suppose optimistic rollups are a technical solution to a social problem
